Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Use a protractor to measure the angles of each quadrilateral. Complete the table to organize your results. (The notation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi><mo>∠</mo><mi>A</mi></math>  denotes the measure of angle <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> .)
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Use a protractor to measure the angles of each quadrilateral. Complete the table to organize your results. (The notation m angle symbol A  denotes the measure of angle A .)

Sheet1.Caption: How precise are your measurements?
Sheet1.VO: How precise are your measurements?

Sheet1.Expl Title: Solving for the Angle Measures of a Polygon
Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to be sure your answers make sense in the context of the problem. For instance, if you find the angle measures of a triangle, and they have a sum that is not equal to 180°, then you should check your work for mistakes.
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. The sum <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>S</mi></math> of the angle measures of a polygon with <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi></math> sides can be found using the formula <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>S</mi><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><mn>180</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Write and solve an equation to find each value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math>. Justify the steps in your solution. Then find the angle measures of each polygon.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. The sum S of the angle measures of a polygon with n sides can be found using the formula S is equal to 180 times n minus 2. Write and solve an equation to find each value of x. Justify the steps in your solution. Then find the angle measures of each polygon.

Sheet1.Expl Title:
Solving an Absolute Value
Equation Algebraically
Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Consider the absolute value equation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>∣</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>∣</mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Describe the values of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo> </mo><mo>+</mo><mo> </mo><mn>2</mn></math> that make the equation true. Use your description to write two linear equations that represent the solutions of the absolute value equation.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Consider the absolute value equation absolute value of x plus 2 is equal to 3. Describe the values of x plus 2 that make the equation true. Use your description to write two linear equations that represent the solutions of the absolute value equation.

Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to explain to yourself the meaning of a problem and look for entry points to its solution.
Sheet1.Caption: Use the linear equations you wrote in part (a) to find the solutions of the absolute value equation.
Sheet1.VO: Use the linear equations you wrote in part (a) to find the solutions of the absolute value equation.

Sheet1.Caption: How can you use linear equations to solve an absolute value equation?
Sheet1.VO: How can you use linear equations to solve an absolute value equation?

Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Write an inequality for each statement. Then sketch the graph of the numbers that make each inequality true. Statement: The temperature <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi></math> in Sweden is at least <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>-</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>°</mo><mi>C</mi></math>.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Write an inequality for each statement. Then sketch the graph of the numbers that make each inequality true. Statement The temperature "t" in Sweden is at least minus 10 degree Celcius.

Sheet1.Caption: Statement: The elevation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>e</mi></math> of Alabama is at most <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2407</mn></math> feet.
Sheet1.VO: Statement The elevation "e" of Alabama is at most 2407 feet.

Sheet1.Expl Title: Solving an Absolute Value Inequality Graphically
Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Consider the absolute value inequality <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>|</mo><mi>x</mi><mo> </mo><mo>+</mo><mo> </mo><mn>2</mn><mo>|</mo><mo> </mo><mo>≤</mo><mo> </mo><mn>3</mn></math>. On a real number line, locate the point for which <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo> </mo><mo>+</mo><mo> </mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><mn>0</mn></math>.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Consider the absolute value inequality absolute value of x plus 2 is less than or equal to 3. On a real number line, locate the point for which x plus 2 is equal to 0.

Sheet1.Caption: Locate the points that are within 3 units from the point you found in part (a). What do you notice about these points?
Sheet1.VO: Locate the points that are within 3 units from the point you found in part (a). What do you notice about these points?

Sheet1.Caption: How can you use a number line to solve an absolute value inequality?
Sheet1.VO: How can you use a number line to solve an absolute value inequality?

Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Determine whether each relation represents a function. Explain your reasoning.

Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text:
To be proficient in math, you need to routinely interpret your results in the context of the situation. The reason for
studying mathematics is to enable you to model and solve real-life problems.
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. The graph shows the cost of a smartphone plan. What is the <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math>-intercept of the line? Interpret the <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math>-intercept in the context of the problem.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. The graph shows the cost of a smartphone plan. What is the y-intercept of the line? Interpret the y-intercept in the context of the problem.

Sheet1.Caption: Approximate the slope of the line. Interpret the slope in the context of the problem.
Sheet1.VO: Approximate the slope of the line. Interpret the slope in the context of the problem.

Sheet1.Caption: Write an equation that represents the cost as a function of data usage.
Sheet1.VO: Write an equation that represents the cost as a function of data usage.

Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Caption: The point (<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>x</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo></mrow></msub><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>) is a given point on a nonvertical line. The point (<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>y</mi></math>) is any other point on the line. Write an equation that represents the slope <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi></math> of the line. Then rewrite this equation by multiplying each side by the difference of the <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math>-coordinates to obtain the point-slope form of a linear equation.
Sheet1.VO: The point x 1 comma y 1 is a given point on a nonvertical line. The point x comma y is any other point on the line. Write an equation that represents the slope m of the line. Then rewrite this equation by multiplying each side by the difference of the x-coordinates to obtain the point-slope form of a linear equation.

Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Match each linear inequality with its graph.

Sheet1.Caption: Explain how the number of solutions of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>relates to the graph of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></math>.

Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Solve the system of equations by graphing each equation and finding the points of intersection.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Solve the system of equations by graphing each equation and finding the points of intersection.

Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. The functions <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>g</mi></math> are inverses of each other. Compare the tables of values of the two functions. How are the functions related?
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. The functions f and g are inverses of each other. Compare the tables of values of the two functions. How are the functions related?

Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. The graphs show the weights of the players on a professional football team and a professional baseball team. Describe the data in each graph in terms of how much the weights vary from the mean. Explain your reasoning
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. The graphs show the weights of the players on a professional football team and a professional baseball team. Describe the data in each graph in terms of how much the weights vary from the mean. Explain your reasoning

Sheet1.Caption: Compare how much the weights of the players on the football team vary from the mean to how much the weights of the players on the baseball team vary from the mean.
Sheet1.VO: Compare how much the weights of the players on the football team vary from the mean to how much the weights of the players on the baseball team vary from the mean.

Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to reason inductively about data, making plausible arguments that take into account the context from which the data arose.
Sheet1.Caption: Does there appear to be a correlation between the body weights and the positions of players in professional football? in professional baseball? Explain.
Sheet1.VO: Does there appear to be a correlation between the body weights and the positions of players in professional football? in professional baseball? Explain.

Sheet1.Subject: A1
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. You are the manager of a sports shop. The two-way tables show the numbers of soccer T-shirts in stock at your shop at the beginning and end of the selling season. Complete the totals for the rows and columns in each table.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. You are the manager of a sports shop. The two-way tables show the numbers of soccer T-shirts in stock at your shop at the beginning and end of the selling season. Complete the totals for the rows and columns in each table.

Sheet1.Caption: No
Sheet1.VO: No

Sheet1.Caption: How would you alter the number of T-shirts you order for next season? Explain your reasoning.
Sheet1.VO: How would you alter the number of T-shirts you order for next season? Explain your reasoning.

Sheet1.Subject: A2
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. The graph shows a quadratic function of the form <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo> </mo><mo>+</mo><mo> </mo><mi>b</mi><mi>t</mi><mo> </mo><mo>+</mo><mo> </mo><mi>c</mi></math>which approximates the yearly profits for a company, where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></math> is the profit in year <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi></math>. Is the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi></math> positive, negative,or zero? Explain.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. The graph shows a quadratic function of the form P of t is equal to "a" t squared plus "b" t plus c which approximates the yearly profits for a company, where p of t is the profit in year t. Is the value of a positive, negative, or zero? Explain.

Sheet1.Caption: Write an expression in terms of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>b</mi></math> that represents the year <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi></math> when the company made the least profit.
Sheet1.VO: Write an expression in terms of a and b that represents the year t when the company made the least profit.

Sheet1.Caption: The company made the same yearly profits in 2004 and 2012. Estimate the year in which the company made the least profit.
Sheet1.VO: The company made the same yearly profits in 2004 and 2012. Estimate the year in which the company made the least profit.

Sheet1.Caption: Assume that the model is still valid today. Are the yearly profits currently increasing, decreasing, or constant? Explain.
Sheet1.VO: Assume that the model is still valid today. Are the yearly profits currently increasing, decreasing, or constant? Explain.

Sheet1.Subject: A2
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Match each sequence with its graph. The horizontal axes represent <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi></math>, the position of each term in the sequence.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Match each sequence with its graph. The horizontal axes represent n, the position of each term in the sequence.

Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to reason inductively about data.
Sheet1.Caption: Write a rule for the <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi></math>th term of the sequence, and use the rule to find <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>10</mn></msub></math>.
Sheet1.VO: Write a rule for the nth term of the sequence, and use the rule to find a 10.

Sheet1.Subject: A2
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Look at the infinite geometric series given below. Write a conjecture about how you can determine whether the infinite geometric series <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo> </mo><mo>+</mo><mo> </mo><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mi>r</mi><mo> </mo><mo>+</mo><mo> </mo><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo> </mo><mo>+</mo><mo> </mo><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><msup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo> </mo></mrow></msup><mo> </mo><mo>+</mo></math>. . . has a finite sum.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Look at the infinite geometric series given below. Write a conjecture about how you can determine whether the infinite geometric series "a" 1 plus "a" 1 r plus "a" 1 r 2 plus "a" 1 r 3 plus and so on has a finite sum.

Sheet1.Subject: A2
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. You learned that the sum of the first <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi></math> terms of a geometric series with first term <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and common ratio <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>r</mi><mo> </mo><mo>≠</mo><mo> </mo><mn>1</mn></math> is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mfenced><mfrac bevelled="true"><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mi>n</mi></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>r</mi></mrow></mfrac></mfenced></math> . When an infinite geometric series has a finite sum, what happens to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>r</mi><mi>n</mi></msup></math> as <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi></math> increases?  Explain your reasoning.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. You learned that the sum of the first n terms of a geometric series with first term a subscript 1 baseline and common ratio r is not equal to 1 is S n is equal to "a" 1 times 1 minus r n over 1 minus r. When an infinite geometric series has a finite sum, what happens to r to the n th power as n increases? Explain your reasoning.

Sheet1.Caption: Write a formula to find the sum of an infinite geometric series.
Sheet1.VO: Write a formula to find the sum of an infinite geometric series.

Sheet1.Subject: A2
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. To overcome the imbalance of standard playing dice, one of the authors invented and patented 12-sided dice, on which each number from 1 through 6 appears twice (on opposing sides). As part of the patent process, a standard playing die was rolled 27,090 times. The results are shown below. What can you conclude from the results of this experiment? Explain your reasoning.

To overcome the imbalance of standard playing dice, one of the authors invented and patented 12-sided dice, on which each number from 1 through 6 appears twice (on opposing sides). As part of the patent process, a standard playing die was rolled 27,090 times. The results are shown below. What can you conclude from the results of this experiment? Explain your reasoning.

Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Consider a unit of length that is equal to the length of the diagonal which is about 5.8 inches. Call this length “1 diag.” How tall are you in diags? Explain how you obtained your answer.

Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to justify your conclusions and communicate them to others.
Sheet1.Caption:
Work with a partner. Use the Venn diagram to determine whether the statement is true or false. Justify your answer. Assume that no region of the Venn diagram is empty. 
If an item has Property B, then it has Property A.
Sheet1.VO:
Work with a partner. Use the Venn diagram to determine whether the statement is true or false. Justify your answer. Assume that no region of the Venn diagram is empty. 
If an item has Property B, then it has Property A.

Sheet1.Caption: If an item has Property A, then it has Property B.
Sheet1.VO: If an item has Property A, then it has Property B.

Sheet1.Caption: If an item has Property A, then it has Property C.
Sheet1.VO: If an item has Property A, then it has Property C.

Sheet1.Caption: Some items that have Property A do not have Property B.
Sheet1.VO: Some items that have Property A do not have Property B.

Sheet1.Caption: If an item has Property C, then it does not have Property B.

Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. On a piece of paper, draw two perpendicular lines. Label them <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>C</mi><mi>D</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math>.Look at the diagram from different angles. Do the lines appear perpendicular regardless of the angle at which you look at them? Describe all the angles at which you can look at the lines and have them appear perpendicular.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. On a piece of paper, draw two perpendicular lines. Label them  line AB and line CD. Look at the diagram from different angles. Do the lines appear perpendicular regardless of the angle at which you look at them? Describe all the angles at which you can look at the lines and have them appear perpendicular.

Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to state the meanings of the symbols you choose.
Sheet1.Caption:
Work with a partner. When you draw a diagram, you are communicating with others. It is important that you include sufficient information in the diagram. Use the diagram to determine which of the following statements you can assume to be true. Explain your reasoning.
All the points shown are coplanar.
Sheet1.VO:
Work with a partner. When you draw a diagram, you are communicating with others. It is important that you include sufficient information in the diagram. Use the diagram to determine which of the following statements you can assume to be true. Explain your reasoning.
All the points shown are coplanar.

Sheet1.Caption: Points <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>D</mi></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>G</mi></math>, and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>I</mi></math> are collinear
Sheet1.VO: Points D, G, and I are collinear

Sheet1.Caption: Points <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>C</mi></math>, and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>H</mi></math> are collinear.
Sheet1.VO: Points A, C, and H are collinear.

Sheet1.Caption: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>G</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>H</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math> are perpendicular.
Sheet1.VO: Line E G and line A H are perpendicular.

Sheet1.Caption: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>∠</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>A</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>∠</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>D</mi></math> are a linear pair.
Sheet1.VO: Angle B C A and Angle A C D are a linear pair.

Sheet1.Caption: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>F</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math> are penpendicular.
Sheet1.VO: Line A F and line B  D are perpendicular.

Sheet1.Caption: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>G</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math> are parallel.
Sheet1.VO: Line E G and line B D are parallel.

Sheet1.Caption: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>F</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math> are coplanar.
Sheet1.VO: Line A F and line B  D are coplanar.

Sheet1.Caption: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>G</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math> do not intersect.
Sheet1.VO: Line E G and line B D do not intersect.

Sheet1.Caption: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>F</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math> intersect.
Sheet1.VO: Line A F and line B  D intersect.

Sheet1.Caption: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>G</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math> are perpendicular.
Sheet1.VO: Line E G and line B D are perpendicular.

Sheet1.Caption: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>∠</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>D</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>∠</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>F</mi></math> are vertical angles.
Sheet1.VO: Angle A C D and Angle B C F are vertical angles.

Sheet1.Caption: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>H</mi></mrow><mo>↔</mo></mover></math> are the same line.
Sheet1.VO: Line A C and line F H are the same line.

Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. In previous courses, you studied different properties, such as the properties of equality and the Distributive, Commutative, and Associative Properties. Write the property that justifies each of the following solution steps.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. In previous courses, you studied different properties, such as the properties of equality and the Distributive, Commutative, and Associative Properties. Write the property that justifies each of the following solution steps.

Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to look closely to discern a pattern or structure.
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. The symbols <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>♦</mo></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>•</mo></math> represent addition and multiplication (not necessarily in that order). Determine which symbol represents which operation.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. The symbols diamond and circle represent addition and multiplication (not necessarily in that order). Determine which symbol represents which operation.

Sheet1.Caption: State each algebraic property being illustrated.
Sheet1.VO: State each algebraic property being illustrated.

Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to know and be able to use algebraic properties.
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Four steps of a proof are shown. Write the reasons for each statement. Given <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo> </mo><mo>+</mo><mo> </mo><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math>. Prove <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Four steps of a proof are shown. Write the reasons for each statement. Given A C is equal to A B plus A B. Prove A B is equal to B C.

Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Six steps of a proof are shown. Complete the statements that correspond to each reason. Given <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi><mo>∠</mo><mn>1</mn><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><mi>m</mi><mo>∠</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Prove <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi><mo>∠</mo><mi>E</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>A</mi><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><mi>m</mi><mo>∠</mo><mi>C</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi></math>.
Sheet1.VO:
Work with a partner.  Six steps of a proof are shown. Complete the statements that correspond to each reason. Given measure of angle 1 is equal to measure of angle 3.
Prove measure of angle E B A is equal to measure of angle C B D.

Sheet1.Expl Title: Matching Reasons in a Flowchart Proof
Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to map relationships using such tools as diagrams, two-way tables, graphs, flowcharts, and formulas.
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Match each reason with the correct step in the flowchart. Given <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo> </mo><mo>+</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math>. Prove <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>
Sheet1.VO:
Work with a partner. Match each reason with the correct step in the flowchart. Given A C is equal to A B plus A B. 
Prove A B is equal to B C.

Sheet1.Expl Title: Matching Reasons in a Flowchart Proof
Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Match each reason with the correct step in the flowchart. Given <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi><mo>∠</mo><mn>1</mn><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><mi>m</mi><mo>∠</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Prove <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi><mo>∠</mo><mi>E</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>A</mi><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><mi>m</mi><mo>∠</mo><mi>C</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi></math>.
Sheet1.VO:
Work with a partner. Match each reason with the correct step in the flowchart. 
Given measure of angle 1 is equal to measure of angle 3. 
Prove measure of angle E B A is equal to measure of angle C B D

Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to know and flexibly use different properties of operations and objects.
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner.  A right triangle with legs <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi></math> , <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo> </mo><mi>b</mi></math> , hypotenuse <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>c</mi></math> , and altitude from <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>C</mi></math> to  <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></mrow><mo>¯</mo></mover></math>  is shown. The lengths are labelled. Explain why <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>△</mo><mo> </mo><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> , <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>△</mo><mo> </mo><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>D</mi></math>, and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>△</mo><mo> </mo><mi>C</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi><mo> </mo></math> are similar.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. A right triangle with legs a, b, hypotenuse c , and altitude from C to line segment AB is shown. The lengths are labelled. Explain why triangle A B C, triangle A C D, and triangle C B D are similar.

Sheet1.Caption: Write a two-column proof using the similar triangles in part (b) to prove that <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo> </mo><mo>+</mo><mo> </mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><msup><mi>c</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>
Sheet1.VO: Write a two-column proof using the similar triangles in part (b) to prove that a squared plus b squared is equal to c square

Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to express numerical answers witha degree of precision appropriate for the problem context.
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Use a calculator that has a tangent key to calculate the tangent of  36.87°. Do you get the result = 0.75? Explain.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Use a calculator that has a tangent key to calculate the tangent of  36 point 87 degrees. Do you get the result  is equal to 0 point 75? Explain.

Sheet1.Expl Title: Finding the Length of a Circular Arc
Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Caption:
Work with a partner. Find the length of each red circular arc. 
entire circle
Sheet1.VO:
Work with a partner. Find the length of each red circular arc. 
entire circle

Sheet1.VO: one-fourth of a circle

Sheet1.VO: one-third of a circle

Sheet1.VO: five-eighths of a circle

Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. The rider is attempting to stop with the front tire of the motorcycle in the painted rectangular box for a skills test. The front tire makes exactly one-half additional revolution before stopping. The diameter of the tire is 25 inches. Is the front tire still in contact with the painted box? Explain.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. The rider is attempting to stop with the front tire of the motorcycle in the painted rectangular box for a skills test. The front tire makes exactly one-half additional revolution before stopping. The diameter of the tire is 25 inches. Is the front tire still in contact with the painted box? Explain.

Sheet1.Expl Title: Finding the Area of a Sector of a Circle
Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Caption:
Work with a partner. A sector of a circle is the region bounded by two radii of the circle and their intercepted arc. Find the area of each shaded circle or sector of a circle.
entire circle
Sheet1.VO:
Work with a partner. A sector of a circle is the region bounded by two radii of the circle and their intercepted arc. Find the area of each shaded circle or sector of a circle.
entire circle

Sheet1.VO: one-fourth of a circle

Sheet1.VO: seven-eighths of a circle

Sheet1.Caption: two-thirds of a circle
Sheet1.VO: two-thirds of a circle

Sheet1.Expl Title: Finding the Area of a Circular Sector
Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to explain to yourself the meaning of a problem and look for entry points to its solution.
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. A center pivot irrigation system consists of 400 meters of sprinkler equipment that rotates around a central pivot point at a rate of once every 3 days to irrigate a circular region with a diameter of 800 meters. Find the area of the sector that is irrigated by this system in one day.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. A center pivot irrigation system consists of 400 meters of sprinkler equipment that rotates around a central pivot point at a rate of once every 3 days to irrigate a circular region with a diameter of 800 meters. Find the area of the sector that is irrigated by this system in one day.

Sheet1.Expl Title: Finding the Area of a Regular Polygon
Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.HTML Instruction Text: Work with a partner. Use dynamic geometry software to construct each regular polygon with side lengths of 4, as shown. Find the apothem and use it to find the area of the polygon.
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Use dynamic geometry software to construct each regular polygon with side lengths of 4, as shown. Find the apothem and use it to find the area of the polygon.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Use dynamic geometry software to construct each regular polygon with side lengths of 4, as shown. Find the apothem and use it to find the area of the polygon.

Sheet1.Caption: No
Sheet1.VO: No

Sheet1.Caption: No
Sheet1.VO: No

Sheet1.Caption: No
Sheet1.VO: No

Sheet1.Caption: Describe the steps that you used.
Sheet1.VO: Describe the steps that you used.

Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to know and flexibly use different properties of operations and objects.
Sheet1.Caption:
Work with a partner. Use the following steps to develop a formula for the area of a regular polygon.

Step 1 : Find the center of the regular n-gon by finding the center of its circumscribed circle. Then find the apothem.

Step 2 : Use the center to divide the n-gon into n congruent triangles, each with a base that is a side of the n-gon and a height that is the apothem.

Step 3 : Find the area of one triangle and multiply by n to find the area of the regular n-gon.
Sheet1.VO:
Work with a partner. Use the following steps to develop a formula for the area of a regular polygon.

Step 1 : Find the center of the regular n-gon by finding the center of its circumscribed circle. Then find the apothem.

Step 2 : Use the center to divide the n-gon into n congruent triangles, each with a base that is a side of the n-gon and a height that is the apothem.

Step 3 : Find the area of one triangle and multiply by n to find the area of the regular n-gon.

Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. The five Platonic solids are shown below. Each of these solids has congruent regular polygons as faces. Complete the table by listing the numbers of vertices, edges, and faces of each Platonic solid.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. The five Platonic solids are shown below. Each of these solids has congruent regular polygons as faces. Complete the table by listing the numbers of vertices, edges, and faces of each Platonic solid.

Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to communicate precisely to others.
Sheet1.Caption:
Work with a partner. Consider a stack of square papers that is in the form of a right prism.
 
What is the volume of the prism?
Sheet1.VO:
Work with a partner. Consider a stack of square papers that is in the form of a right prism.
 
What is the volume of the prism?

Sheet1.Caption: When you twist the stack of papers, as shown above, do you change the volume? Explain your reasoning.
Sheet1.VO: When you twist the stack of papers, as shown above, do you change the volume? Explain your reasoning.

Sheet1.Caption: Write a carefully worded conjecture that describes the conclusion you reached in part (b).
Sheet1.VO: Write a carefully worded conjecture that describes the conclusion you reached in part (b).

Sheet1.Caption: Use your conjecture to find the volume of the twisted stack of papers.
Sheet1.VO: Use your conjecture to find the volume of the twisted stack of papers.

Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Caption:
Work with a partner. Use the following conjecture to find the volume of the cylinder. 
If two solids have the same height and the same cross-sectional area at every level, then they have the same volume.
Sheet1.VO:
Work with a partner. Use the following conjecture to find the volume of the cylinder. 
If two solids have the same height and the same cross-sectional area at every level, then they have the same volume.

Sheet1.Caption: No
Sheet1.VO: No

Sheet1.Expl Title: Finding the Volume of a Pyramid
Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to look closely to discern a pattern or structure.
Sheet1.Caption:
Work with a partner. The pyramid and the prism have the same height and the same square base.
When the pyramid is filled with sand and poured into the prism, it takes three pyramids to fill the prism. 
Use this information to write a formula for the volume <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>V</mi></math> of a pyramid.
Sheet1.VO:
Work with a partner. The pyramid and the prism have the same height and the same square base.
When the pyramid is filled with sand and poured into the prism, it takes three pyramids to fill the prism. 
Use this information to write a formula for the volume V of a pyramid.

Sheet1.Expl Title: Finding the Volume of a Pyramid
Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Use the formula <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>V</mi><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>B</mi><mi>h</mi></math> to find the volume of the hexagonal pyramid.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Use the formula V is equal to one thirds B h  to find the volume of the hexagonal pyramid.

Sheet1.Expl Title: Finding the Surface Area of a Cone
Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Caption:
Work with a partner. Construct a circle with a radius of 3 inches. Mark the circumference of the circle into six equal parts, and label the length of each part. Then cut out one sector of the circle and make a cone. 
Explain why the base of the cone is a circle. What are the circumference and radius of the base?
Sheet1.VO:
Work with a partner. Construct a circle with a radius of 3 inches. Mark the circumference of the circle into six equal parts, and label the length of each part. Then cut out one sector of the circle and make a cone. 
Explain why the base of the cone is a circle. What are the circumference and radius of the base?

Sheet1.Caption: What is the area of the original circle? What is the area with one sector missing?
Sheet1.VO: What is the area of the original circle? What is the area with one sector missing?

Sheet1.Caption: Describe the surface area of the cone, including the base. Use your description to find the surface area.
Sheet1.VO: Describe the surface area of the cone, including the base. Use your description to find the surface area.

Sheet1.Expl Title: Finding the Volume of a Cone
Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to understand and use stated assumptions, definitions, and previously established results in constructing arguments.
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. The cone and the cylinder have the same height and the same circular base. When the cone is filled with sand and poured into the cylinder, it takes three cones to fill the cylinder. Use this information to write a formula for the volume <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>V</mi></math> of a cone.
Sheet1.VO:
Work with a partner. The cone and the cylinder have the same height and the same circular base.

 When the cone is filled with sand and poured into the cylinder, it takes three cones to fill the cylinder.

Use this information to write a formula for the volume V of a cone.

Sheet1.Expl Title: Finding the Surface Area of a Sphere
Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Additional Info Button Text: To be proficient in math, you need to identify relevant external mathematical resources, such as content located on a website.
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. Remove the covering from a baseball or softball. You will end up with two “figure 8” pieces of material, as shown above. From the amount of material it takes to cover the ball, what would you estimate the surface area <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>S</mi></math> of the ball to be? Express your answer in terms of the radius <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>r</mi></math> of the ball.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. Remove the covering from a baseball or softball. You will end up with two “figure 8” pieces of material, as shown above. From the amount of material it takes to cover the ball, what would you estimate the surface area S of the ball to be? Express your answer in terms of the radius r of the ball.

Sheet1.Expl Title: Finding the Volume of a Sphere
Sheet1.Subject: GE
Sheet1.Caption: Work with a partner. A cylinder is circumscribed about a sphere, as shown. Write a formula for the volume <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>V</mi></math> of the cylinder in terms of the radius <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>r</mi></math>.
Sheet1.VO: Work with a partner. A cylinder is circumscribed about a sphere, as shown. Write a formula for the volume V of the cylinder in terms of the radius R.

Sheet1.Caption: When half of the sphere (a hemisphere) is filled with sand and poured into the cylinder, it takes three hemispheres to fill the cylinder. Use this information to write a formula for the volume <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>V</mi></math> of a sphere in terms of the radius <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>r</mi></math>.
Sheet1.VO: When half of the sphere (a hemisphere) is filled with sand and poured into the cylinder, it takes three hemispheres to fill the cylinder. Use this information to write a formula for the volume V of a sphere in terms of the radius R.
